pullRequest.body:
These instances are now in the `UIntX.CommRing` scope.

This is because the presence of these casting operations contradicts assumptions made by the
expression tree elaborator, namely that coercions do not form a cycle.
This happens in `Fin` and `BitVector` too, but those are problems for another PR.

After this change, `ring`, `norm_num`, and `rw [mul_add_one]` no longer work out of the box on these types.
To avoid further fallout (`rw [mul_one]`, `abel`, ...), `CommMonoid` and `NonUnitalCommRing` instances are provided, which fall just short of enabling the unwanted cast operators.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
> I'm a little wary of this change, even if adjusted to use a scope; the same problem exists for Fin and is far more prevalent, so what do we gain by introducing an inconsistency and fixing it only for these types?

The alternative is just deleting this instance, not leaving as is. I would like to improve the situation for `Fin` down the line, but that problem *must not* become an excuse for not fixing this problem. (Consistently bad is not a good thing.)

I've pushed some changes (to avoid using up your time asking you to make them yourself), namely:
* Combining the `Cast` and `CommRing` scopes; I can't think of any reason you'd want one and and not both open
* Adjusting the docstring to mention `Fin`
* Adding docstrings to the three offending instances

If these look good to you modulo small tweaks, then

bors d+

:v: semorrison can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge
Canceled.

Sorry, I thought of one more thing; we can safely add the instances which don't come with a cast, which I've done here.

Without these, even things like `rw [add_comm]` break. I've edited the PR description to explain this.
@eric-wieser Can we merge this now?
Yes, sorry; I didn't merge myself to give Kim or Kyle time to object to the extra commit I pushed
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9409620077/job/25919888107)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9409620077/job/25919888285)

I'm a little wary of this change, even if adjusted to use a scope; the same problem exists for Fin and is far more prevalent, so what do we gain by introducing an inconsistency and fixing it only for these types?

I'm a little wary of this change, even if adjusted to use a scope; the same problem exists for Fin and is far more prevalent, so what do we gain by introducing an inconsistency and fixing it only for these types?

This isn't true; the coercion is defined higher up in the file; this just proves it's lawful.

So if we go down this route there are three instances to disable for each type, not one. I think asking the user to refer to these individually by name is unreasonable, and so we should scope them.

```suggestion
The UInt
```

@eric-wieser The `Fin` problem is on my radar.

I don't see any inconsistency with fixing the problem for `UInt*` types and putting off fixing `Fin`. The `Fin` type is arguably mathematical, but the `UInt*` types clearly aren't (they're the integers modulo arbitrary powers of two).

Mentioning `Fin` at all just makes it more likely that we'll have an inconsistency in documentation once the `Fin` problem is fixed. It seems unlikely to me that anyone modifying `Fin` instances would think to look at `Mathlib.Data.UInt`'s module docs.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Data/UInt): make instCommRing a def, and explain why
